knowledge.markdown:
# Erdős #48 - Infinitely Many φ(n) = σ(m) Pairs

## Problem Statement

Are there infinitely many integers n, m such that φ(n) = σ(m)?

## Status

**Erdős Database Status**: SOLVED

**Solution**: Ford-Luca-Pomerance (2010) proved YES

## Verified Example Pairs

| n | m | φ(n) = σ(m) |
|---|---|-------------|
| 2 | 1 | 1 |
| 5 | 3 | 4 |
| 7 | 5 | 6 |
| 13 | 11 | 12 |
| 13 | 6 | 12 |

## Twin Prime Connection

If p and p+2 are both prime:
- φ(p+2) = (p+2) - 1 = p + 1
- σ(p) = 1 + p = p + 1

So (p+2, p) is a φ-σ pair!

The twin prime conjecture would immediately imply this result.
